subject: p11879886
History: Acute-on-chronic shortness of breath, diastolic CHF, known metastatic leiomyosarcoma, CAD status post CABG, question pneumonia, pulmonary edema. CHEST, SINGLE AP PORTABLE VIEW. Rotated positioning. The patient is status post sternotomy, with cardiomegaly. There is upper zone redistribution and diffuse vascular blurring, consistent with CHF. The left hemidiaphragm is elevated, likely accentuated by what appears to be air within the fundus, dilating the gastric fundus. Aside from some increased retrocardiac density, no frank consolidation or gross effusion is identified.
Impression: CHF with upper zone redistribution and diffuse vascular blurring. Minimal left lower lobe opacity also noted. Of note, the chest CT from described innumerable pulmonary nodules. It would be difficult to distinguish interstitial metastatic disease from the findings on the current study, but the upper zone redistribution and overall blurring does appear more pronounced than on and that rapid change supports the diagnosis of CHF.
